titleStmt.title: A pleasant [d]ialogue between a Protestant school-boy, and a Popish priest concerning the present times, as they met at Hide-Park corner, last Fryday. [Illegible] particularly, touching Popish saints, transubstantiation, infallibility, bulls, limbus patrum, miracles of the meal-tub, Monmouth's business, the race at Salisbury, &c. Also, something relating to the late unhappy fire at Whitehall.

titleStmt.title: A pleasant [d]ialogue between a Protestant school-boy, and a Popish priest concerning the present times, as they met at Hide-Park corner, last Fryday. [Illegible] particularly, touching Popish saints, transubstantiation, infallibility, bulls, limbus patrum, miracles of the meal-tub, Monmouth's business, the race at Salisbury, &c. Also, something relating to the late unhappy fire at Whitehall.

Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: A Plea • ant • IALOGUE BETWEEN A Protestant School-Boy, And a Popish PRIEST, Concerning the Present Times, •… s they met at Hide-Park Corner, last Fryday.
•… o Particularly, touching Popish Saints, Transubstantiation, •… fallibility▪ Bulls, Limbus Patrum, Miracles of the Meal-Tub, •… onmouth's business, the Race at Salisbury, &c.
•… lso, something relating to the late unhappy Fire at Whitehall.

figure.q: well met Child direct the to heauen.

div.head: 〈…〉 Dialogue betwixt a Boy and a Papist.

sp.p:
HA boys Tom, go carry home my Tops, my Giggs, my Marbles and •… y Nicks, yonder comes the Man I told you •… f, that taught me to keep so many Holy-days: •… y, go, I say, for I'll play no longer, but •… and at the Corner, and salatue him, it may •… e he may teach me a trick more pleasant than 〈…〉 breaking up at Easter, Whitsontide, or
•… hristmas.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
Well then Jack, adieu till Night, I'll •… e no Eves-dropper to over-hear your Argu
•… ents. Farewel Tom. Now for a touch of •… y Grandmother at Rome-ave Domine, hail, •… r.

p.hi: O my Child, well met, I have been •… oking for thee to Instruct thee in some farther •… rinciples: How hast thou improved thy self in •… hat I taught thee last?

sp.p:
Well, Sir, as to observing of the Ho
•… y- • ays, for I have plaid the Truant at least Twenty times, as our Scholars tell me my Ma
•… er says, since I converst with you.

p.hi:
O Heretick, would not he then have •… hee observe those days the Pope has set a-part
to be Religiously kept, as sanctified Holy-da •…

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, but vows he'll whip me soun •… when ever I come to School again; and ind •… I believe he'll be as good as his word, for 〈…〉 is a cruel man.

p.hi:
Well, thou shalt be no more under s •…
jection to a Heretick, but be instructed by Pedagogue of ours; these damn'd Heretick •… know would ruine thee, but I'll prevent th •… and take care for thy future Education.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O law Sir, what's that Pedagog •… ha! that's a fine Name indeed, pray w •… manner of thing is it:

p.hi:
Why one that shall teach thee to rec •… all the Articles of thy Belief, and only rest 〈…〉 Salvation on the Pope's Infallibility; but co •… up little Knave, what Holy-days did you so stri •…
ly observe, name them?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why, all those Catholick Saints da •… that have been Hanged for Treason, ever si •… Queen Besses days, as they call her.

p.hi: O Villain, for Treason: no, but t •… dye Martyrs for the holy Church, under 〈…〉 Heretical Persecutions.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Well then, that died Martyrs, as Gui •… Faux, Catesby, Bookwood, Piercy, Digby,
〈…〉 the like, with Father Garner, Staely, Colem •… Langhorn, all the Jesuits, and a number mo •… I took them all for Saints, because they ma •… up the more Holy-days to keep me from 〈…〉 School.

p.hi: 'Tis very well you did, and must ever •… fter hold them to be Saints; or else be plung'd •… nto Eternal Torments.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Well, Sir, but as to the Pope's Infal
•… bility, pray has the Pope no Sin? cannot he •… rr like other Men?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p:
No, 'tis a mortal Sin, and does de
•… erve the hottest Flames of Purgatory to once 〈…〉 much as think he can; all that he does is •… uer than the Scriptures, all is Gospel that he •… eaks, or be it what it will, he makes it so; •… ay, he will have it so in spight of all the He
•… eticks.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why, truly Sir, I heard my Father call •… im Whore of Babylon, and I am sure Whores •… re counted naughty People here in England.

p.hi:
Ay, thy poor Father was a damn'd He
•… etick, and would have made thee so, but thou •… ust not believe a word he taught thee, but re
•… ounce him as I told thee, and acknowledge no •… ther Father but the Pope, you must believe he is •… nfallible and cannot sin.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if it must be so.—

p.hi: Must, yes upon pain of Damnation it •… ust, to think a thought to the contrary, deserves the Flames.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Yet farther, Sir, I heard our Minister •… nce say (and Ministers with us are counted •… oly Men) that he was a Scarlet Beast, with seven Heads and ten Horns, and I am sure
that such a Beast must needs be ugly and monstrous too, for I never heard of such a one i •…
England, unless it was the Ram that wa •… shown in Bartholomew-Fair, and that too ha •… but one Head, though it had many Horns; pray, Sir, is he like a Ram?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p:
Sirrah, leave off these blasphemous Qu •…
ries, or I shall teach you better manners, th •… same way we taught the Hereticks in blesse •… Queen Mary's days.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, how was that?

p.hi: Why with Fire and Faggot, Sirrah •… which Lesson we intend to read them o'er agai •… ere long, if our business succeds.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O law, Sir, why did you bake the •… in Ovens and make Pasties of them to fee •… the Pope?

p.hi: No, Rogue, but chain'd them to 〈…〉 Stake, and burnt them to ashes: but more 〈…〉 this hereafter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Why Sir, 'tis said the Roman Cath •…
licks do use to bake their God, and eat hi •… up, well then may they devour an hundre •… such poor humane Squabs as I.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Thou damn'd Heretick, I'll sacrifi •… thee up to Molech, if thou dar'st say the li •… again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O pray, Sir, I'll do any thing, O, fo •… the sake of St. Franeis, Sir, don't eat me.

p.hi:
No Villain, I shan't, and yet because 〈…〉
see how false thy Heretical Parents have taught thee, on purpose thou mightest be damned; I will in pity instruct thee somewhat about the Omnipotence of Transubst •• tiation.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O law, Sir, that is such a hard word, I shall forget it, pray chalk it up on my Hat, for my better remembrance.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, but on thy back with a Discipline, as we did on Langhorn's, for discovering of the Jesuits Lands, if thou dar'st be thus unmannerly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, I have done; now you may inform me what you please.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Well then, Transubstantiation is by the power of the holy Mother Church, and the Omnipotence of our infallible Father the Pope, by turning of a Wafer by Consecration of the Priest into a Corporal body.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Alas! Sir, I hope the Pope is not a Conjurer, for I heard my Father say, they can do no very strange things; I wondred indeed from whence the Gypsies came all this while, and now I perceive they came from Rome; I hope, Sir, all your Priests are not Gypsies, if they be, they will gabble so that I shall not be able to understand one word they say.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p:
Sirrah, will you never leave these thwarting questions, Rascal, I charge thee no more on 'em, O damn'd Heretick the Pope a Conjurer, and our Priests Gypsies, I shall give
thee up to be tormented in the hottest hole o •…
Purgatory.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O pardon me, Sir, I wou'd have said the Pope a Thunderer, and your Priests, Jesuits 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Well turn'd Rogue, I see thou cans •… equivocate by Mental Reservation, ay, now tho •… sayest right, for the Pope is a Boanerger, a So •… of Thunder, witness his Roaring Bulls agains •… Excommunicated Princes, how soon these Thunderbolts can ruine Kingdoms, by stirring up Religion, and unhinge the State of Empire.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Alas! Sir, how chance his Holines •… sent none of these horned Beasts into Englan •…
to do his work, for a mad Bull is a very fearful thing, Oh how they will buck one, if the •… stand but in their way; for I have seen the •… play sad Tricks in Smithfield.

p.hi: Alas, poor Child! I see thou art ignorant in that Affair, and knowest not what they b •…

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O law, Sir, not know what a Bull is 〈…〉 Ha, ha, ha, and avads, my Father kept tw •… among his Cows; why, Sir, they have tw •… short Horns, and a great pair of Stones; O law, not know what a Bull is! sure you tak •… me for a great Fool indeed.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p:
Sirrah, I say you are mistaken, th •…
Pope's Bulls are other manner of things, one 〈…〉 them ruin'd Bohemia, Albigensia, Piedmont and Waldensia, and caused Eight hundre •… thousand Hereticks to die.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
O fie upon his Horns, what a murder
•… g Bull was that! 'tis well then that we have 〈…〉 one of 'em in England, such a Bull would •… eat all London before him, and swallow up
•… aul's at a mouthful, and drink the River of
•… hames dry, so that the Water-men would •… e forced to go a Hay-making, avads, that •… ould be pretty.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Yes Sirrah, there has been one of them •… ately in England, but that Air is so thick, and •… he Climate so cold, that he could not roar •… oud nough, nor cast out his Flames around •… im, as in other Countries, more subject to the •… ee of Rome.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Alas! if they be fiery Bulls, and cast •… ut Flames so, that might be one of them (for •… ught I know) which roar'd so loud and fu
•… iously at Whitehall last Week, for I remem
•… er abundance of Flames flew about, tho •… he Weather was very cold at that time; be
•… ides, some People discourse as if some of the Sons of your Church was concern'd in that dismal Conflagration.

p.hi: No, Impudence; 'tis well known how that unhappy Fire began, tho some lewd Hereticks have maliciously endeavour'd to make •… eople believe strange things, in order to render us odious, but I would have you to know, we scorn all such abominable Actions.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Ay, I believe you do, but 'tis as Dog scorns Mutton, when he runs away wit •… whole Shoulders.

p.hi: Come, come, thou art a very Wag, I s •… thou understands not what these kind of Bul •… are gendred of, nor whence they do derive the •… Power.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No indeed Sir, I know no other tha •… I have told you; but pray Sir, make me f •… to understand, I'de gladly know.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p:
Why Sirrah, they are Bulls of Basha •…
made to push at Princes, to make them bow b •…
fore the See Apostolick, or else by Excommun •…
cating them, to tear the Crowns from off the •… Heads Depose and Murther them by their ow •… Subjects Hands, as France and England, Ge •…
many and Spain in former Ages had their M •…
narchs served—but no more of this.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
But pray Sir, one Question more, for 〈…〉 would fain learn what Bulls these are; w •… not that one of them that the Pope's Lega •… brought over to Excommunicate King Hen •…
the 8th?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then I know what they are, for 〈…〉 heard my Father read in an old Book, tha •… that Legate was Hang'd at Tyburn with h •… Bull about his Neck; sure that was a simp •… Bull that could not roar the Gallows dow •… when others did such Feats as you relate.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Villain, 'tis Death for thee to say those •… ords again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O—Sir—hold—I have done.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p:
Tis well thou hast, or I should stop •… y Breath for ever, and purge thee of t • y He
•… sie, in the dark Cells of Limbus Patrum.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Alas, Sir, what kind of place is that, 〈…〉 have heard much talk of Bugby's-hole; nay, •… y Sister told me I should go thither, is that •… e Limbus Patrum you mean Sir, fo • I'll war
•… nt you that's some ugly place or other, for •… e very naming on't so scar'd me, that I could •… ot eat my Breakfast.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: No, no, Sirrah, it is a place exceeding •… at a thousand times, a place where naughty •… eople go to purge themselves of Sin in streams •… f Fire.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O law, Sir, what that's a kind of an •… gly place indeed; but pray Sir, have they •… o Victuals there?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why, good Sir, how can they live •… hen? I hope they don't do as they say the Bears do in Greenland?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: How is that, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why, sit upon their Tails, and suck •… heir Paws all Winter, instead of Breakfast, Dinner and Supper.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: No Rogue, they don't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why, pray Sir, can they live upon nothing, that's a hard case?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Yes, upon nothing but Heat and Smoa •…

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Avads, then I believe it is the pla •… from whence our Tobacco comes, for the •… they say, the people eat little or nothing b •… Smoak; and besides, the people are curse •… black that come from thence, therefore I b •…
lieve it must be a damnable hot Country.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p:
No Rascal, 'tis another kind of pla •… and smoke than that, 'tis a place within 〈…〉 Inch of Hell, just under our Feet, with Ad •…
mantine Gates, of which the Pope does a •…
ways keep the Keys. 'tis Purgatory, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Alas! Sir, I don't know, but I veri •… believe 'tis the same place as I mean, for I a •…
sure I ne'er smelt no Smoke stink worse tha •… Tobacco-smoke in my life, and all people sa •… that it comes from a place under us; nay, a •… further, I have heard people say that ha •… been at the bottom of a deep Well, that th •… have heard the Ducks quak in anoth •… World; and now, Sir, I believe verily th •… were mistaken, and that it was only the P •…
soners in Purgatory, calling for Drink to the •… Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
Ha! Villain, 'tis a Mystery, 'tis a M •…
racle beyond thy Capacity, I charge thee 〈…〉 speak no more on't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Well, I shan't Sir, but now you ta •…
of a Miracle, I have heard much discourse o • Miracles; pray Sir, what manner of thing is a Miracle?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: A Miracle is some wondrous work, wrought by the Church of Rome; as raising •… he Dead, healing the Blind and the Lame, causing Images to Speak, &c. These properly •… elong to her alone, and are performed by the Clergy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But Sir, they say the Plot in Monmouth's days, was discovered by a Miracle, did •… our Church discover that I pray now?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p:
No, no, thou art damn'd if thou be
•… ievest that ever there was any Plot, only an •… nvention of the Devil and the Presbyterians,
•… o raise a Persecution against the Saints, and •… ou must believe so on pain of Purgatory.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: But Sir, as to the Discovery, (I heard •… olks say,) the Meal-Tub made, had your Church no hand in that, if I might be so bold?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p:
Yes, I do believe that was a Miracle •… rought by the Church Apostolick, by way •… f Transubstantiation, turning the Meal into •… ritten Papers, and had it not been so mole
•… ted as it was, all the Meal had taken the same •… orm, and filled the Land with flying News of •… he Pope.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Alas Sir, if your Church could do such Tricks, she may turn all your Meal to Paper, •… nd then what should we do for Pancakes on
•… hrove-Tuesday.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p:
No, no, Sirrah, all our Miracles r •…
ther tend to the good of Mankind than a •… ways to prejudice them, especially that pa •… which belongs to Mother Church.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Oh, oh, now I understand you, a •… in part the nature of your Miracles too, fo •… remember in 88, there was a mighty Fema •… which brought forth a Son (as I may say) 〈…〉 an Hours warning, which was a swinging M •…
racle, and I suppose wrought by your Churc •…

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Thou art in the right on't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
As right as I am, I believe your M •…
racles ceased suddainly after, for when the Dut •…
Landed at Torbay, your party could perfor •… none, unless some Wonders by out-runni •… the Dutch at Saliihury-Plain.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Nay, for all your hast, there was so •… Miracles perform'd too, viz. in preserving t •… Babie and his Mother from the terrible Ja •… of Meenhere, and the reputed Dadda also.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
But hold Sir, with your leave, if yo •… Church could have work'd such Wonders 〈…〉 you talk of, she would have preserved S •…
John Friend and Sir William Perkins, fro •… that unlucky and fatal Jobb they perform •… at Tyburn, as also another holy Brother, who •… Head took leave of him at Tower-Hill, M •…
racles in those Days I am sure would ha •… been very acceptable among the Sons of yo •… Church.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p:
Out upon thee, thou Saucy Villain, let 〈…〉 have no more of these Reflections; Satan •… s let loose then, so that no Miracle could •… ke place; but he will be bound again e'er •… ng, and then you'l see our Miracles will re
•… ve again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Nay, then I humbly beg your Pardon, •… r saying your Army ran away for fear of the
•… utch; for if Satan was let loose at that time, 〈…〉 rather think he appeared among them at
•… alisbury, for as the Proverb says, They must •… eeds go (and run too) when the Devil •… rives.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Come, I see you're a Wag, let's have 〈…〉 Catch, and so conclude.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Now you talk of a Catch, it puts me 〈…〉 mind of the Hang-man, and therefore I be
•… ieve you would have me sing to the Tune of
•… t. Coleman and the five Jesuits.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: No Sirrah, that's too serious to make 〈…〉 Song on.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Oh Sir, 'tis the better, for it is like singing a Psalm at Tyburn.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Why, you don't think I shall be Hang'd, do ye you Knave;

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I don't know, but if you go on as you begin, you may prosper so well as to be Sainted at last, and much good may do you with it.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Come, leave your joaking, and let's have the Song, but let's have no Heresie in't I charge you.

div.head: The SONG;
div.opener: To the Tune of Clories awake: Or, I am a Maid, &c.
div.l: THE Papist's Religion will crrtainly please;
For that will Indulge it to live at our ease;
And if we have Peter-pence, fear not the Story
Of the wide Mouth of Hell, or the Hole Purgatory,
The Pope and Jack Ketch has made many Saints,
And yet all the Papists are full of Complaints?
But there is no reason I think for this thing,
When Jack sends them all up to Heaven in a String.

div.p: London, Printed by R.G. in Little Britain, 169 •…
